triples.name: Echo chamber
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes echo chambers as a key phenomenon emerging in social networks that limits exposure to diverse perspectives.

triples.name: Political polarization
triples.relevance: Polarization is a central phenomenon the paper models, examining how extreme opinion divergence emerges in social networks.

triples.name: Misinformation
triples.relevance: The paper discusses misinformation spread as a concern linked to echo chambers and polarization in social media.

triples.name: Radicalization
triples.relevance: The paper introduces radicalization dynamics as a novel reinforcing mechanism driving evolution toward extreme opinions.

triples.name: Social network
triples.relevance: The paper models the dynamics of opinion evolution and polarization within social networks as fundamental structures.

triples.name: Homophily
triples.relevance: The paper incorporates homophily as a key agent characteristic alongside heterogeneous activity levels in the model.

triples.name: Social influence
triples.relevance: The paper identifies social influence as a primary mechanism governing the transition between consensus and radicalized states.

triples.name: Twitter
triples.relevance: The paper validates the model by comparing simulations with empirical data from polarized debates on Twitter.

triples.name: Agent-based model
triples.relevance: The paper proposes an agent-based model with heterogeneous agents to simulate the emergence of echo chambers and polarization.

triples.name: Mathematical models of social learning
triples.relevance: The paper models opinion dynamics using mathematical frameworks inspired by empirical social interaction dynamics.
